message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Logic of Conditional Doxastic Actions
Paper Abstract: We present a logic of conditional doxastic actions, obtained by incorporating ideas from belief revision theory into the usual dynamic logic of epistemic actions. We do this by reformulating the setting of Action-Priority Update (see Baltag and Smets, 2008) in terms of conditional doxastic models, and using this to derive general reduction laws for conditional beliefs after arbitrary actions.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, I found several meanings of "Dynamic logic" depending on the context:

## Modal Logic (Theoretical Computer Science)

In logic, philosophy, and theoretical computer science, dynamic logic is an extension of modal logic capable of encoding properties of computer programs.(no content)Dynamic logic was developed by Vaughan Pratt in 1974 in notes for a class on program verification and was later published in 1976 as a logical system in its own right.(no content)Beyond its use in formal verification of programs, dynamic logic has been applied to describe complex behaviors arising in linguistics, philosophy, AI, and other fields.

## Digital Electronics

Dynamic logic is distinguished from so-called static logic in that dynamic logic uses a clock signal in its implementation of combinational logic.(no content)In dynamic logic, a clock signal is used to evaluate combinational logic.

## Dynamic Epistemic Logic

Dynamic epistemic logic (DEL) is a logical framework dealing with knowledge and information change. Typically, DEL focuses on situations involving multiple agents and studies how their knowledge changes when events occur.

The term "dynamic logic" can therefore refer to different concepts depending on whether you're discussing computer science theory, digital electronics, or philosophical logic.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Dynamic epistemic logic (DEL) is a logical framework dealing with knowledge and information change. Typically, DEL focuses on situations involving multiple agents and studies how their knowledge changes when events occur.

The term "dynamic logic" can therefore refer to different concepts depending on whether you're discussing computer science theory, digital electronics, or philosophical logic.

Here are the search results for **Doxastic logic**:

## Overview

Doxastic logic is a type of logic concerned with reasoning about beliefs.(no content)The term doxastic derives from the Ancient Greek δόξα (doxa, "opinion, belief").

## Notation and Application

Typically, a doxastic logic uses □, often written "B", to mean "It is believed that", or when relativized to a particular agent s, "It is believed by s that".

## Key Concepts

In doxastic logic, researchers study various types of reasoners with different properties:

- **Stable reasoners**: A stable reasoner is not unstable.
- **Unstable reasoners**: An unstable reasoner is one who believes that they believe some proposition, but in fact does not believe it.
- **Type 1 reasoners**: A type 1 reasoner has a complete knowledge of propositional logic i.e., they sooner or later believe every tautology/theorem. Also, their set of beliefs (past, present and future) is logically closed under modus ponens.

## Related Concepts

Doxastic logic is related to epistemic modal logic, which deals with reasoning about knowledge and belief. The field also connects to philosophical topics like doxastic logic; however, as opposed to other philosophical views on belief, doxastic voluntarism claims each human agent as the author of their own beliefs.

Web search results for query: "Belief revision theory"

Links: [{"title":"Belief revision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief_revision"},{"title":"Conservatism (belief revision) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservatism_(belief_revision)"},{"title":"Category:Belief revision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Belief_revision"},{"title":"Revision theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revision_theory"},{"title":"Fallibilism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fallible"},{"title":"Belief - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief"},{"title":"Belief merging - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief_merging"},{"title":"Peter Gärdenfors - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_G%C3%A4rdenfors"},{"title":"Theory of mind - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/False_belief"},{"title":"Belief perseverance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief_perseverance"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of belief revision theory:

## Definition and Scope

Belief revision (also called belief change) is the process of changing beliefs to take into account a new piece of information.(no content)The logical formalization of belief revision is researched in philosophy, in databases, and in artificial intelligence for the design of rational agents.

## Key Challenges

What makes belief revision non-trivial is that several different ways for performing this operation may be possible. For example, if the current knowledge includes three conflicting facts, consistency can be done preserving consistency only by removing at least one of the three facts. In this case, there are at least three different ways for performing revision.

## Important Framework: The AGM Postulates

The AGM postulates (named after their proponents Alchourrón, Gärdenfors, and Makinson) are properties that an operator that performs revision should satisfy in order for that operator to be considered rational.

## Related Concepts

Belief revision theory distinguishes between different operations: Revision and merging differ in that the first operation is done when the new belief to incorporate is considered more reliable than the old ones; therefore, consistency is maintained by removing some of the old beliefs. Merging is a more general operation, in that the priority among the belief sets may or may not be the same.

The theory continues to be an active area of research in formal epistemology, addressing fundamental questions about how rational agents should update their beliefs when confronted with new information.

Web search results for query: "Epistemic logic"

Links: [{"title":"Epistemic modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_modal_logic"},{"title":"Dynamic epistemic logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_epistemic_logic"},{"title":"Doxastic logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doxastic_logic"},{"title":"Epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemology"},{"title":"Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_logic"},{"title":"KK thesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KK_thesis"},{"title":"Masked-man fallacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masked-man_fallacy"},{"title":"Aristotle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle"},{"title":"Talk:Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Modal_logic"},{"title":"Talk:Epistemic modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Epistemic_modal_logic"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about epistemic logic:

## Overview

Epistemic modal logic is a subfield of modal logic that is concerned with reasoning about knowledge.(no content)As a logic, it is concerned with understanding the process of reasoning about knowledge and belief: which principles relating the notions of knowledge and belief are intuitively plausible?

## Applications and Development

Epistemic logic is a much more recent development with applications in many fields, including philosophy, theoretical computer science, artificial intelligence, economics, and linguistics.

The field emerged relatively recently in formal logic. It was not until 1962 that Jaakko Hintikka would write Knowledge and Belief, the first book-length work to suggest using modalities to capture the semantics of knowledge rather than the alethic statements typically discussed in modal logic.

## Key Concepts

The basic modal operator of epistemic logic, usually written K, can be read as "it is known that," "it is epistemically necessary that," or "it is inconsistent with what is known that not."(no content)Most attempts at modeling knowledge have been based on the possible worlds model. In order to do this, we must divide the set of possible worlds between those that are compatible with an agent's knowledge, and those that are not.

## Extensions

Epistemic logic has been combined recently with some ideas from dynamic logic to create dynamic epistemic logic, which can be used to specify and reason about information change and exchange of information in multi-agent systems.

Epistemic logic has been combined recently with some ideas from dynamic logic to create dynamic epistemic logic, which can be used to specify and reason about information change and exchange of information in multi-agent systems.
